title: "Taylor series"
---

## From Taylor polynomials to series {#sec-taylor-series}

Suppose $f:I\to\mathbb{R}$ is infinitely differentiable (all derivatives exist and are continuous). Then for each $n$ we can form a Taylor polynomial $T_n$ at a point $a\in I$, and write
$$
f(x)=T_n(x)+R_n(x).
$$

Now consider the sequence of polynomials
$$
T_0,\,T_1,\,T_2,\ldots
$$
If for a given $x$ we have
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty} R_n(x)=0,
$$
then
$$
f(x)=\lim_{n\to\infty}T_n(x),
$$
and the limit may be representable as a **power series**.

## Example: the exponential function {#sec-exp-series}

For $f(x)=e^x$ at $a=0$,
$$
T_n(x)=\sum_{k=0}^n \frac{x^k}{k!}.
$$
Taylorâ€™s Theorem gives a remainder term of the form
$$
R_n(x)=\frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}\,x^{n+1}
=\frac{e^{\xi}}{(n+1)!}\,x^{n+1},
\qquad \xi\in(0,x).
$$

Assume $x>0$. Then $0<\xi<x$ implies $e^{\xi}\le e^x$, so
$$
|R_n(x)|\le e^x\frac{|x|^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}.
$$

To see that the right-hand side goes to $0$ as $n\to\infty$, define $a_n:=\frac{x^n}{n!}$. Then
$$
\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|=\frac{|x|}{n+1}\to 0.
$$
Hence $a_n\to 0$, and therefore $R_n(x)\to 0$. Consequently,
$$
e^x=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n!}.
$$
(You can check the case $x<0$ similarly.)

## Example: the geometric series {#sec-geom-series}

Consider $f(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}$ on $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{1\}$. One has the identity
$$
\frac{1}{1-x}=1+x+x^2+\cdots=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}x^n
\qquad \text{for }x\in(-1,1).
$$

Compute derivatives:
$$
f^{(k)}(x)=\frac{k!}{(1-x)^{k+1}}.
$$
At $a=0$,
$$
f^{(k)}(0)=k!,
$$
so the Taylor polynomial at $0$ is
$$
T_n(x)=\sum_{k=0}^n\frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}x^k=\sum_{k=0}^n x^k
=1+x+x^2+\cdots+x^n.
$$
On $(-1,1)$ these Taylor polynomials converge to $f(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}$, but not on the full domain.

## Example: sine and cosine series {#sec-sin-cos-series}

For $f(x)=\sin x$ at $a=0$,
$$
T_{2n+1}(x)=\sum_{k=0}^n(-1)^k\frac{x^{2k+1}}{(2k+1)!}.
$$
The remainder satisfies (using $|\sin|\le 1$ and $|\cos|\le 1$)
$$
|R_n(x)|\le \frac{|x|^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\to 0\quad (n\to\infty),
$$
so
$$
\sin x = x-\frac{x^3}{3!}+\frac{x^5}{5!}-\cdots.
$$

Similarly,
$$
\cos x = 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\cdots.
$$
Both series have radius of convergence $R=\infty$.
